articles.headline: Obama Wins Crucial Senate Vote on F-22
articles.snippet: The vote in the Senate to delete financing for new F-22s was a victory for President Obama in his efforts to reshape the military’s priorities.
articles.abstract: The vote in the Senate to delete financing for new F-22s was a victory for President Obama in his efforts to reshape the military’s priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With some of his political capital on the line, President Obama won a crucial victory on Tuesday when the Senate voted to strip out $1.75 billion in financing for seven more F-22 jet fighters from a military authorization bill.

articles.headline: Pinch of Reality Threatens the California Dream
articles.snippet: Three decades of population growth, budget problems and the rising cost of social services are being felt in California.
articles.abstract: Three decades of population growth, budget problems and the rising cost of social services are being felt in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Even in the 1930s, Woody Guthrie warned America in a Dust Bowl song that the California dream could not be had on the cheap. Yet relative to other places, the state has historically been a pretty good bargain, with a low-cost, enviable higher education system, subsidized energy and an abundance of services for those down on their luck.

articles.headline: Sales Drive Robust Quarter for Apple
articles.snippet: The company’s quarter was led by sales of Macintosh computers and a burst in iPhone purchases, after the introduction of the new 3GS.
articles.abstract: The company’s quarter was led by sales of Macintosh computers and a burst in iPhone purchases, after the introduction of the new 3GS.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  While earnings have faltered at other electronics companies, unexpectedly strong sales of Macintosh computers and a surge in iPhone purchases pushed Apple’s profit up 15 percent in the third quarter, the company said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Radical Islamists Slip Easily Into Kenya
articles.snippet: The Shabab, a militia that has taken over much of southern Somalia, is considered a threat to Westerners living in Kenya.
articles.abstract: The Shabab, a militia that has taken over much of southern Somalia, is considered a threat to Westerners living in Kenya.
articles.lead_paragraph: HULUGHO, Kenya  A thin, dusty line is about the only thing separating Kenya, one of the Western world’s closest allies in Africa, from the Shabab, a radical Islamist militia that has taken over much of southern Somalia, beheading detractors, stoning adulterers and threatening to kill any Americans or Europeans who get in their way.

articles.headline: Artists Find Backers as Labels Wane
articles.snippet: Companies are planning to invest in artists who lack record deals and help them find audiences online.
articles.abstract: Companies are planning to invest in artists who lack record deals and help them find audiences online.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time when most aspiring musicians had the same dream: to sign a deal with a major record label.

articles.headline: Pakistan Objects to U.S. Plan for Afghan War
articles.snippet: Pakistani officials have told the U.S. that the Marines fighting the Taliban in southern Afghanistan will force militants across the border into Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Pakistani officials have told the U.S. that the Marines fighting the Taliban in southern Afghanistan will force militants across the border into Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan is objecting to expanded American combat operations in neighboring Afghanistan, creating new fissures in the alliance with Washington at a critical juncture when thousands of new American forces are arriving in the region.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Costly Drugs Known as Biologics Prompt Exclusivity Debate
articles.snippet: Companies that own the rights to high-end treatments say allowing copycats to market too soon would hurt financial incentives.
articles.abstract: Companies that own the rights to high-end treatments say allowing copycats to market too soon would hurt financial incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bitter Congressional fight over the cost of superexpensive biotechnology drugs has come down to a single, hotly debated number: How many years should makers of those drugs be exempt from generic competition?

articles.headline: Challenge to Health Bill: Selling Reform
articles.snippet: Health care will cost the typical American household roughly $15,000 this year, but many don’t notice how much they’re paying.
articles.abstract: Health care will cost the typical American household roughly $15,000 this year, but many don’t notice how much they’re paying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  What’s in it for me?

articles.headline: Clinton Speaks of Shielding Mideast From Iran
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton stiffened the American line against Iran.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton stiffened the American line against Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHUKET, Thailand — Stiffening the American line against Iran, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned Wednesday that the United States would consider extending a “defense umbrella” over the Middle East if the country continued to defy international demands that it halt work that could lead to nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Obama Moves to Reclaim the Debate on Health Care
articles.snippet: President Obama sought to convince an increasingly skeptical American public that proposed changes to the health care system would benefit them and strengthen the economy.
articles.abstract: President Obama sought to convince an increasingly skeptical American public that proposed changes to the health care system would benefit them and strengthen the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama tried on Wednesday to rally public support for overhauling the nation’s health care system and said for the first time that he would be willing to help pay for the plan by raising income taxes on families earning more than $1 million a year.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Red Ink Stains Bank and Banker
articles.snippet: John J. Mack, Morgan Stanley’s longtime chief executive, is toning down the risk-taking as he tries to revive the bank and burnish his legacy.
articles.abstract: John J. Mack, Morgan Stanley’s longtime chief executive, is toning down the risk-taking as he tries to revive the bank and burnish his legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: John J. Mack has spent a long, storied career helping to build Morgan Stanley into a modern Wall Street powerhouse. But suddenly, the lights have dimmed inside the House of Mack, leaving its hard-charging leader fighting for his legacy.

articles.headline: Government Takes Over Delphi’s Pensions
articles.snippet: The federal government would take over the pension plans of the Delphi Corporation at a cost of $6.2 billion.
articles.abstract: The federal government would take over the pension plans of the Delphi Corporation at a cost of $6.2 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government said Wednesday that it would take over the pension plans of the Delphi Corporation at a cost of $6.2 billion, after years of demanding that the assets of the company and its former corporate parent, General Motors, be used instead.
